instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
Could <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> be a problem? I went down the rabbit hole of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. 

The hot spot is about 38 degree..

[ATTACH type="full"]59475[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
First post diode mode to ground at L7130 and L7095.
Also post <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
L7130 - 0.131
L7095 - 0.000

Tested Red to ground and on both sides of chip.

Does that Mean I have a short on PP3v42?

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
1 - 0.6V
2 - 335mv
3 - 1.6444v
4 - 0.542v
5 - - 
6 - 17.52v
7 - - 
8 - 17.54v
9 - -

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
For sure...

Safe to inject voltage there; start with 1V and go up if needed, no more than 4V.
Don't forget to set current limit at max on your PSU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
Hello

So I have removed L7095 and the short is on Pin 2 not pin 1, so does that rule out issues with <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> ?

Just to confirm before I blow up the board...

Positive is soldered to Pin 2 of L7095
Ground is soldered to a nearby screw hole
Power Supply is set to 1v 
Amps is set to max 5 (that's it's max)

... and I am looking for what gets hot using alcohol or the thermal camera?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
Exactly.
If there is pure short, 5A PSU can enter protection even with 1V.
If this happens, try 0.7-0.8V.
In such case will be dificil to find the culprit.

Consider to get  24V/20A PSU for this purpose.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/33014847184.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.27426c37hyCAfx[/URL]
You can go for 12V/40A even.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message: Had a quick look with thermal cam only thing that gets hot is <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
Is time to change the SMC.
However, check again diode mode there, once SMC is removed; before soldering other chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message: I have checked Diode mode again, I get 0.337. Is it worth re-balling old SMC, or do I just go straight for a new one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message: If short gone after removing SMC, need to change it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message: How cross compatible are the SMC's ? Does it need to be from the exact same board number?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Boot
threads.message:
Always use SMC from donot board, to prevent any issue.

3476/3536 SMCs are interchangable, but not sure about other good equivalency.
